The claim mentions that 18 riders completed at least 6 laps. Let's count how many riders there are in total. Looking at the data array, I see there are 17 entries. So each row represents a rider, making it 17 riders total. 

Now, out of these 17, Chris Vermeulen only did 6 laps and retired. The others all have 22 laps, which is more than 6. So how many riders completed at least 6 laps? That would be the 17 minus those who didn't complete even 6 laps. But looking at the data, everyone except Chris has 22 laps, so they definitely did more than 6. Chris has exactly 6 but he retired, which might mean he stopped before finishing, but he still completed 6 laps.

Wait, does the claim say "complete" as in finished all laps, or just started at least 6? The wording is a bit ambiguous. But typically, "complete" would mean finishing the race with that many laps. However, Chris's status is retirement, so maybe he didn't finish. So perhaps he only attempted 6 laps but didn't complete them.

If we consider that, then how many riders actually completed at least 6 laps? It's the total number of riders who finished, which would be everyone except Chris. That makes 16 riders who completed all 22 laps, and one rider (Chris) who only did 6 before retiring.

Wait, but does the claim specify that they completed at least 6 laps in terms of finishing? Or just started or attempted 6 laps? The wording is a bit unclear. But given that Chris's time is "retirement" and he has 6 laps, perhaps it means he only did 6 and didn't finish.

So if the claim is about completing (finishing) at least 6 laps, then all riders except Chris completed 22 laps. So 17 - 1 = 16 riders completed more than 6 laps. But wait, actually, everyone who finished has 22 laps, which is way above 6. So that's 16 riders (since Chris didn't finish). 

But the claim says 18 riders completed at least 6 laps. Wait, but there are only 17 entries in total. That's a problem because the maximum possible number of riders completing any laps would be 17. So if the claim is saying 18, that can't be true.

Alternatively, perhaps Chris Vermeulen did complete 6 laps and then retired, so he technically completed 6 laps but didn't finish the race. In that case, all 17 riders completed at least 6 laps. But the claim says 18, which is more than the total number of riders in the data (which is 17). So regardless of whether Chris counts or not, it's impossible to have 18 riders because there are only 17.

Therefore, the claim that 18 riders completed at least 6 laps must be FALSE.
</think>
